G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action involves a residential tenancy within the City of Boston, Suffolk County.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises. Violation of this covenant entitles the tenant to actual and consequential damages, or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus attorneys’ fees and costs.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Continuous water intrusion and uninhabitable dampness render the premises unsafe and unfit for human habitation, violating G.L. c. 111, § 127A, § 127B, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127B.proposition: Continuous water intrusion and uninhabitable dampness render the premises unsafe and unfit for human habitation, violating G.L. c. 111, § 127A, § 127B, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.000 et seq..proposition: Continuous water intrusion and uninhabitable dampness render the premises unsafe and unfit for human habitation, violating G.L. c. 111, § 127A, § 127B, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Defendant’s apparent retaliatory conduct in refusing to renew Plaintiff’s lease after she reported housing code violations further constitutes indirect interference with quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and violates the anti-retaliation provisions of G.L. c. 186, § 18.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts leasehold interest.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that G.L. c. 186, § 14 "codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment," and discusses that covenant as a background rule applicable to landlord‑tenant relationships in Massachusetts. By treating the covenant as an implied, pre‑existing incident of tenancies that the statute codified and modified, the case supports the proposition that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts leasehold interest.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts leasehold interest.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to an "implied" covenant or warranty of quiet enjoyment as the basis for the tenants’ constructive eviction defense, and it treats this covenant as a standard incident of the landlord-tenant relationship without suggesting it depends on express language in the lease. Although the court does not explicitly state that the covenant is implied in "every" Massachusetts leasehold, its discussion assumes the existence of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in these residential leases as a settled rule, which supports the general proposition. The support is somewhat indirect, hence medium confidence.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were "very substantially deprived" of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises "for a substantial time" (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge).... Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair the water infiltration problem after notice from Plaintiff and from the city constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that the landlord’s failure to prevent repeated, unsanitary flooding—despite notice and a duty to maintain watertight, sanitary conditions—constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion emphasizes Gem’s repeated inaction after complaints and recognizes that such omission, in violation of sanitary-code obligations, made Gem liable for interference with quiet enjoyment. Although the damages award on that count was later vacated as duplicative, the liability holding on substantial interference with quiet enjoyment remains intact.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Continuous water intrusion and uninhabitable dampness render the premises unsafe and unfit for human habitation, violating G.L. c. 111, § 127A, § 127B, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.000 et seq.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses that the State Sanitary Code and G.L. c. 111, §127A et seq. set mandatory minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and that violations may render an apartment uninhabitable, but it does not specifically address continuous water intrusion or dampness, nor does it clearly hold that such conditions, as a matter of law, violate the cited statutes and regulations. The opinion is focused on the legal framework for implying a landlord’s obligation based on code violations generally, not on particular findings regarding water intrusion or dampness in this case. Thus it is too general and indirect to be strong authority for the specific proposition about continuous water intrusion and uninhabitable dampness.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit… which does not comply’ with its provisions… I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards… .”

McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.raw_text: McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Mass. 300 (1999)
McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.proposition: A breach of the State Sanitary Code can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State sanitary and building code violations only in the context of negligence and the implied warranty of habitability, not as an independent basis for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The quiet enjoyment discussion is limited to stating that negligence is a prerequisite for recovery under that theory; it does not say that a breach of the State Sanitary Code itself constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not support the claimed proposition.
McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.relevant_excerpt: We reject the plaintiff’s contention that she is entitled to a new trial based on her claims that the defendant violated the lease and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, G. L. c. 186, § 14. Negligence is a prerequisite for recovery under both theories. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997) (showing of negligence is required for recovery under quiet enjoyment statute)… Both the lease and the State code provisions merely restated a duty which the defendant acknowledged.

Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983)
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s apparent retaliatory conduct in refusing to renew Plaintiff’s lease after she reported housing code violations further constitutes indirect interference with quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and violates the anti-retaliation provisions of G.L. c. 186, § 18.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is about a public housing authority’s eviction of a tenant for allowing drug activity, and analyzes ‘good cause’ for eviction, notice, grievance procedures, and availability of defenses under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. It does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 (quiet enjoyment) or § 18 (anti‑retaliation), nor does it address retaliatory refusal to renew a lease after code-enforcement complaints. The proposition concerns retaliatory, indirect interference with quiet enjoyment and statutory anti‑retaliation rights, which are outside the scope of this decision, so the case does not provide authority for that proposition.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt:
O’Brien argues that the trial judge was in error in refusing to allow her to raise the defense of uninhabitable conditions under G. L. c. 239, § 8A. She concedes that these defenses cannot be raised where an eviction is based upon wrongdoing, or fault, by the tenant. She argues, however, that her eviction was based upon cause and not fault and that she can, therefore, assert uninhabitable conditions.

While cause may not always involve fault by a tenant, cause “is a general term, and must take on much of its meaning from the context in which it is used.” Spence v. Gormley, 387 Mass. at 263.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Defendant’s apparent retaliatory conduct in refusing to renew Plaintiff’s lease after she reported housing code violations further constitutes indirect interference with quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and violates the anti-retaliation provisions of G.L. c. 186, § 18.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any refusal to renew a lease, retaliatory conduct for reporting code violations, interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, or retaliation under G.L. c. 186, § 18. The case instead concerns issues such as heat and hot water obligations, security deposits, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability damages, and G.L. c. 93A’s applicability. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific retaliation/quiet enjoyment proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: The opinion contains no discussion of nonrenewal of a lease, retaliation for reporting code violations, or G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 or 18. The case focuses on: (1) failure to provide utilities and interpretation of the State Sanitary Code; (2) violations of the security deposit statute, G. L. c. 186, § 15B; (3) rent control overcharges under the Boston rent control ordinance; (4) breach of warranty of habitability; and (5) the inapplicability of G. L. c. 93A to an owner-occupant of a three-family dwelling.

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recover damages for the loss of her property, for diminished value of tenancy, and for distress and inconvenience resulting from Defendant’s unlawful interference.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The case concerns a tenant’s recovery against a landlord (a public housing authority) for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court holds that the tenant may recover her ‘actual and consequential damages,’ which here include diminution in rental value and property damage, but it expressly rejects cumulative or punitive recovery beyond actual loss absent statutory authorization, and the trial judge found that emotional distress was not proved. The opinion does not state a general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to damages for diminished value of tenancy, loss of property, and distress and inconvenience as framed in the proposition; rather, it limits recovery to proven actual and consequential damages and notes that emotional distress was not established on the facts. Thus the proposition overstates and mischaracterizes what the case holds.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’… It is clear that the plaintiff’s actual damages exceeded three times her monthly rent of $47. Her actual damages included the diminution of the value of the leasehold due to the breach of the implied warranty of habitability, as well as the damage to her personal property…. The judge found that a claim of emotional distress … had not been proved.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recover damages for the loss of her property, for diminished value of tenancy, and for distress and inconvenience resulting from Defendant’s unlawful interference.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that the tenant is entitled to an assessment of damages and counsel fees under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for the landlord’s failure to provide heat, which is an interference with quiet enjoyment. However, the court does not delineate the specific categories of damages claimed in the proposition (loss of property, diminished value of tenancy, distress and inconvenience); those categories come from other cases such as Simon v. Solomon. Thus, while it supports entitlement to statutory damages generally for unlawful interference, it does not itself articulate the particular damage elements listed in the proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ordering that heat be provided in compliance with the State Sanitary Code without limitation on the amount to be spent by the landlords for fuel; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14… The judgment is reversed and the case remanded… where the tenant may move for an assessment of damages and an award of counsel fees on the quiet enjoyment claim under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”
